title: How to make your money work for you - investing 101
summary: Investing is about building real, long-term wealth that can help you pay for your car, house, and retirement. The biggest mistake people make when they start investing is they try to pick stocks. Instead, focus on asset allocation. Asset allocation means you decide how much of your money you want to invest in different types of assets like stocks, bonds, and cash. The more you diversify your money, the lower the risk of losing money. Investing when youâ€™re young can help earn compound interest over time and grow your money faster.

As a recent college graduate with student loans and rent to pay, let alone the prospect of saving for retirement, you may think investing feels like an impossible task. But it doesn\u2019t have to be. You just need to know where to start.
Investing can be intimidating at first glance. Even high-net-worth individuals struggle finding trustworthy advisors who specialize in helping those with little capital get started in the market\u2014until now. The following simple strategies will help any investor begin investing with little money and see returns over time. In fact, time is the enemy of your money -- the sooner you begin investing for your future, the better off you\u2019ll be.
Working with as little as $10 per month or an initial investment of $100 per month, you can begin to invest for your future. While it\u2019s not necessarily easy to become a successful investor (it does take time and effort), there are simple things you can do to get started on the right foot with minimum risk.
